instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No video on internal display, yes on external
threads.message:
Hey guys, won't lie, still new to this stuff. I will be making good use of this forum since I have several Macs to fix and only so much time to watch LR vids.

I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with no image / video, but works perfectly on an external monitor. History: customer replaced their own screen. I've tested with a known-good, same result.

I did diode mode measurements at the connector pins, and only found that pin 5 is OL (with the screen plugged in).

Also have no backlight, if that helps. Only damage I see is that the bottom left corner of <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> is barely chipped.

Getting .2v on pin 1 @ <RESISTOR>R9014</RESISTOR> (<SIGNAL>LCD_IG_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>). About the same at backlight enable.

Again, on an external monitor the computer works perfectly.

Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No video on internal display, yes on external
threads.message:
Pin 5 is backlight sync pin and is not used.

Seems like LCD is not recognized and all that is needed for that is power to pin 4 and data on pins 6 and 7. Measure these pins with an LCD connected. Also check if these pins have continuity to the end of a separate LCD connector to rule out a bad connector.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No video on internal display, yes on external
threads.message:
My tech is working on this now, and this is what he told me. The screen is known-good, we tested it on another device. He says that he's not getting 3.3v at pins 4, 6, and 7. Still no image / backlight. Also, he says he's getting nothing at the backlight pins. What's next? (Sorry for the late reply, put this to the side for a long time.)

EDIT: He *IS* getting 3.3v at those pins.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No video on internal display, yes on external
threads.message: Before you have an image there will never be backlight of course. There must be 3V on pin 4 at least, check L9008. But pins 6 and 7 should have 3V too and are connected to <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> through pull up resistors <RESISTOR>R9008</RESISTOR>/9. Check voltages on L9008, <RESISTOR>R9008</RESISTOR>/9.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No video on internal display, yes on external
threads.message: He checked those and reports that he's getting 3.3v at all of those points. (I mistakenly typed that he wasn't in my previous post). What's next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No video on internal display, yes on external
threads.message: Check if there is continuity to the other end of a separate LCD cable to verify if the connector is making good contact. This goes for all pins.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No video on internal display, yes on external
threads.message: Continuity checks out on a known good cable.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No video on internal display, yes on external
threads.message:
Then it should work.....You can connect a scope to the SCL and SDA data lines and see if there is any activity. Will be a short burst, so need to do a "capture/one shot" or whatever it is called on your scope.

Also was the LCD replaced because it was cracked or was it replaced because of this problem.
